intro.description: Learn a new guitar chord every day
intro.lesson_description: Before we learn chords, let's understand the basics about the guitar. This lesson is fundamental for your success! Take 15-20 minutes to absorb this content well.
intro.body: Body: The resonance box that naturally amplifies sound. Made of wood, its quality directly influences the instrument's tone
intro.neck: Neck: The long part where you press the strings to form chords and notes. Usually made of resistant wood like mahogany or maple
intro.bridge: Bridge: Fixed piece on the body where strings are attached. Transmits string vibration to the guitar body
intro.headstock: Headstock: End of the neck where the tuning pegs (pins) are located, allowing you to tune strings by turning them to increase or decrease tension
intro.frets: Frets: Metal bars perpendicular to the neck. Each space between frets represents a semitone (half step) in the musical scale
intro.anatomy_tip: Familiarize yourself with these parts by touching and observing your guitar. Understanding anatomy helps in communication with other musicians and instrument maintenance. Extra tip: The sound hole is the opening in the body that projects sound outward.
intro.strings_description: From lowest (thickest) to highest (thinnest). Click 'Play' to hear each string:
intro.strings_phrase: "Eddie Ate Dynamite, Good Bye Eddie" or "Elephants And Donkeys Grow Big Ears"
intro.strings_tip: IMPORTANT: Strings are numbered from bottom to top when you hold the guitar (1st = thinnest/highest, 6th = thickest/lowest). Practice playing each string individually and memorize their sounds. Out-of-tune or very old strings (more than 3-6 months of use) should be replaced.
intro.position_how: How to Hold the Guitar (Sitting Posture):
intro.position_sit: Sit with your back straight and relaxed, feet flat on the floor. Avoid hunching over to see the guitar neck - this causes pain and poor technique
intro.position_leg: Rest the guitar's curve on your right leg (right-handed) or left leg (left-handed). For classical guitar, use a footstool to elevate your left leg
intro.position_right_arm: Right arm rests naturally on the upper part of the guitar body, forearm relaxed. Elbow shouldn't be too high or too low
intro.position_left_hand: Left hand on the neck with thumb positioned behind, approximately in the middle of the neck. Thumb should NOT appear over the top of the neck (except in advanced techniques)
intro.position_left_desc: Left Hand: Forms a natural "C" with thumb behind the neck (usually between 2nd and 3rd fret). Fingers curved, using fingertips to press strings. Short nails are essential! Wrist should be straight, not bent
intro.position_right_desc: Right Hand: Completely relaxed, fingers naturally curved over strings near the sound hole. For fingerpicking: thumb plays bass strings (4th, 5th, 6th), index plays 3rd string, middle plays 2nd, ring plays 1st. For strumming: use thumb or a pick
intro.diagrams_description: Diagrams are like a 'photo' of the guitar neck viewed from the front. Learn to read them and you'll be able to play any chord:
intro.diagrams_vertical: Vertical lines: Represent the 6 guitar strings (left to right: 6th-Low E to 1st-High E)
intro.diagrams_horizontal: Horizontal lines: Represent the frets (spaces on the neck). The thickest line at the top represents the guitar's nut
intro.diagrams_dots: Black dots/circles: Indicate exactly where you should press the strings with your fingers. Press in the space between frets, not on top of the metal bar
intro.diagrams_numbers: Numbers on dots: Indicate which finger to use (1=index, 2=middle, 3=ring, 4=pinky). Thumb is usually not numbered as it stays behind the neck. X = don't play this string. O = play the open string (without pressing)
intro.diagrams_tip: ESSENTIAL TECHNIQUE: Press strings just BEHIND the metal fret (closer to you), not on top of it or in the middle of the space. Use your fingertips and keep them curved. Press firmly enough for clean sound, but don't overdo it (this tires and can cause injuries). If you hear a muted or buzzing sound, adjust finger position.
